Award.AwardTitle: OPUS: ECOLOGICAL AND EVOLUTIONARY PERSPECTIVES ON THE ORIGINS OF COMMUNITY DIVERSITY
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fundamental to preserving the Earth's remarkable biodiversity is an understanding of the processes that determine the number and types of species found locally and regionally. This understanding is even more critical as humans rapidly mix the world's biota and introduce exotic species to new habitats at an increasing rate. This project will synthesize research in the fields of ecology and evolution to fill this gap. Results will significantly advance a major hurdle in fundamental research and in conservation, which is a clearer understanding of how ecological diversity evolves over time. They will also guide efforts to restore ecological communities of conservation concern in the face of species introductions and the invasion of exotic species. Results from this synthesis form the basis for graduate-level courses, will be incorporated as part of Michigan State University's Sparta Nature Program, which introduces incoming freshmen to research questions in the biological sciences, and will contribute to the Michigan Science Olympiad, which fosters learning in science for middle and high school students. Educational benefits are significant, as the project will introduce students at all levels to the value of synthesis across fields of study.

The richness and composition of biological communities vary dramatically in time and space, and the causes of this variation have been the subject of ecological research for decades. The standard model of community assembly is based on the dispersal of species from a regional species pool and filtering by the abiotic and biotic environment to determine which species are successful in colonizing and coexisting at a local site. Ignored in this conceptual framework, however, is the question of how ecological and evolutionary processes interact to generate species pools, differences in the size and composition of these pools among regions, and whether the concept of a regional species pool is biologically valid. This OPUS award will support a collaborative effort to develop, through a series of publications, a synthesis that better incorporates the ecology of species interactions with the geography of speciation to illuminate the evolution of community diversity. Publications resulting from this award will broadly influence thinking by ecologists and evolutionary biologists alike as they address fundamental questions regarding the evolution of ecological communities, and will support graduate training and graduate education, where integration between ecology and evolution is critically needed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A fundamental goal of biology is to determine the processes that generate and maintain the rich diversity of life found on our planet. A critical gap in our understanding of these processes is the interplay between ecology and evolution. This award supported a collaborative effort to develop a synthesis that incorporates the ecology of species interactions (such as competition between species) with the geography of speciation (that is, how do new species arise on the landscape) to better understand how the diversity of life within a geographical region develops over time.

The number of species in a particular region varies dramatically across the surface of the earth. The central focus of the research was to understand how biological communities diversify. This requires answering two questions: 1) How do species form?, and 2) How do different species come together and coexist? There is widespread agreement about the answer to the first question. The conventional view is that species form after populations become isolated by a geographic barrier such as a new mountain range. For example, consider the case of a single species with a wide geographic range that becomes separated into two populations following a volcanic event. Each isolated population adapts to its local conditions and eventually reaches the status of a distinct biological species. This means that individuals from the two populations are no longer able to interbreed and have become distinct in their physical characteristics.

In this example, one species gives rise to two species but there is only one species in a given locality. For diversity to increase in a single locality, at some point, species must come back together and coexist. This is the second question raised above.  The conventional view of this process is that in time, the species become so different that they occupy different ecological niches. If the geographic barrier that caused the initial isolation subsided, one or both species might migrate and come to occupy the same locality. But one critical aspect of this process has been overlooked. Once populations become isolated and adapt to their new environments, their ability to grow, survive and reproduce in other environments is diminished. Although the species might differ ecologically, they may also be poorly suited for living in a new environment.

The term "local adaptation" refers to the common finding from field experiments that populations perform best in their "home" environments. If local adaptation is strong, it should reduce the opportunity for species to expand their range and for local communities to diversify. We reviewed hundreds of scientific papers to test this idea, and found that local adaptation is often very strong. This means that the conventional view of how communities diversify is incomplete. There must be other factors that allow different species to spread despite their local adaptation. One possibility that we pursued is that species come back together after environmental changes alter the habitat to such an extent that all species are affected. In essence, local adaptation is temporarily erased. Such environmental changes may be the result of natural events, or more commonly in today?s world, the result of human impacts on the landscape.

Our results have important implications for modern environments, where habitat alteration is rapidly changing the landscape and is affecting how species interact, and where global commerce has greatly increased the dispersal of species across what were once natural geographical barriers. The introduction of species outside their native ranges can provide underappreciated opportunities to examine the processes that determine the number and types of species found in an ecological community, as well as present enormous challenges to the preservation of native biodiversity.   

Results from this synthesis are provided in a series of peer-reviewed publications, a recent textbook on Community Ecology, through multiple presentations at scientific conferences and seminars, and have been incorporated into graduate-level courses at Michigan State University. This award also supported the training of three Ph.D. students who worked on the project and who have since graduated and are currently in postdoctoral positions.
